jauC8oMUmD7Oxjv-82ZVJw.text: the food was good. The sticky date which another Yelp'er claimed to be excellent was not so good. Not terrible but it had very little dates and tasted strangely smokey. The service and environment was poor to unacceptable. The first ting I noticed was that the kitchen staff (Chef?) who work the grill (which is in plain sight) do not wear any sort of head covering. I find this odd. I guess in the UK it does not matter if hair or dead skin falls into your dishes. In addition to the lack of proper head attire, the head chef kept throwing his dirty pans into a metal bin on the floor which made this very annoying, very loud noise that echoed through the front seating area. I realise he is busy but when the staff give him looks of WTF are you doing you'd think he would stop. Nope! Maybe it is the norm in London, but all the staff (expect for the manager) were not friendly and borderline rude. If do end up going, sit downstairs. I, however, would do not recommend this place.

_ir4_1ZFyXmIhox_XqJCMQ.text: In researching food options for this trip, it struck me as fascinating that some of the restaurants highlighting seasonal British food are simply named after their location.  Hereford Road, Great Queen Street, etc.  So it was on a Sunday evening that I found myself in this posh neighborhood, on the quite street that is Hereford Road.The restaurant is in a former butcher shop.  A stack of rustic bread sat invitingly inside the huge plate glass window.  Once inside, the open kitchen with gleaming white tiles said welcome like nothing else could.  This is where it all happens.  Opposite the kitchen is a wall-length banquette of semi-circular red leather seats with little round bistro tables.  Am I at a milonga in Buenos Aires, waiting for the show to begin?  The host led us down a few steps to the main dining room in the rear.  There were giant red leather booths on one side, and a scattering of wood tables and chairs in the rest of the room.  A humongous circular sky light dominated the middle of the room.  At high noon, I cannot imagine anyone sitting underneath it like ants under a giant magnifying glass.The menu was a single sheet of paper, printed in utilitarian font, listing the day's bounty.  We kicked off the evening with a bottle of Col Vetoraz Prosecco di Valdobbiadene.  For starters, we had Chilled Pea & Lovage Soup, and Grilled Razor Clams, Red Onions, & Savory.  The soup was a refreshing starter.  Sweet creamy peas with hits of astringency from the lovage.  The razor clam was my #1 favorite starter for this whole trip.  They were gigantic, at least 8 inches (see pic on my profile).  They were sweeter than the sweetest of squid, crab, and lobster combined.  A faint smokiness from the grill, and punches of assertiveness from the red onion, herb, and heavily garlic-flavored oil.  For our mains, Baked Brill, Cucumber, Kohlrabi, Brown Shrimps, and Guinea Fowl, Lentils, Sweet Corn, Foie Gras.  Brill is like a turbot.  In my opinion, more like a little stingray.  Very tender mild flesh.  Small brown shrimps seem to be de rigueur with any kind of fish preparation.  The warm salad of cucumber pieces and julienned kohlrabi gave it a nice crunch.  The guinea fowl was nicely roasted with crispy skin.  For a split second I had a vision that I might have shot it myself earlier in the day.  The ragout of lentil and corn was an interesting mix.  The heartiness of lentils combined with the freshness of corn.  Will definitely try this at home.  For pudding, Eton Mess sounded beguiling enough.  Fresh strawberries, meringue, clotted cream, all whipped together into a mess.  Whatever food fight it was that gave birth to this dish, thank you boys!Why 4 stars?  Utter simplicity, but not to the extreme.  Very nice charming place.  An ideal neighborhood restaurant.  Now, how much does one of those white town houses go for?

photos.caption: Photo of Hereford Road - London, United Kingdom. Hereford Road.  Razor clams, red onions, savory.

xjVSMRqInfz9tMgoAjXpSQ.text: Wonderful interior! It's obvious that some real professional had worked on the vision of the restaurant. I think that the prices are acceptable and dishes are fantastic. I really like the romantic and relaxed atmosphere here. This is the most visited restaurant by us.

IXvRAQ3gRf8u0c9nQbFi_g.text: While I appreciated the fact they did not seat us down in the main part of the restaurant because of all the big holiday lunches (this is an ongoing dilemna in my life),  the view we had of the open kitchen was not what I wanted for a Friday lunch.The older of the two chefs was in a cranky mood and was yelling and screaming -- the stuff you expect to hear, but behind the doors of the restauarant.  This was sort of off putting.The food was good - St. John like with very strong starters and moderate to mediocre mains.  The desserts were nothing to write home about so we ordered coffees and then went off in search of something at Carluccio's in Westbourne Grove.Oh yeah, proximity to kitchen means that we kept the memory and scent of Hereford Road with us for the next few days.  That was not a happy scent.

Bb8wJCn2vYgZK-PAMiefnw.text: We liked Hereford Road but it was a bit too British for us.  We did want to try what others have considered the best in British cuisine and are glad we did but probably won't be back.  Our pork entree was tasty but also very fatty.  My wife and I each had a pile of discarded pork debris on our plates by the end.  The sticky date pudding for dessert was well loved and the price of the meal was reasonable enough.  Again, fine meal but just not that memorable or desirable for us.

3F9xGDPQ9V2n1kT0OJ4Eog.text: The menu could be lifted from St John but who cares? Fantastic value set lunches during the week and a menu that won't break the bank anyway, mean this is an incredibly neighbourhood-friendly bistrot. I love seeing unusual and/old fashioned herbs on the menu so was instantly drawn to the mussels with leek and savoury. They were well-seasoned and in a moreish buttered and wined up stock that had me using the soup spoon. The bread did not appear to be from St John Bread & Wine, however was crusty and good and perfect for mopping up juices that my spoon couldn't quite pick up. I can also recommend the onglet with chips. See now, this is great bistrot food. Thick, three-times cooked chips saw me eat the lot against my better judgement and the steak was perfectly cooked and tasty as that cut should be. An interesting and well-priced wine list is worth sampling from - there are some unusual wines in there so definitely ask to taste and to be guided. Can I eat there again tomorrow?

EPqsie3GktwfCy19fC5iZw.text: Brilliant place, quite romantic with its seating style in the front. Have been here 3x and never disappointed. Give it a shot!

b9QeJ6ygtMJt6QUUpQFxXQ.text: my friend who lives in the hood recommended the spot.  she'd hyped as a restaurant from a former member of st. john's.  i was sold.  we had a na early booking at 6:30 and the place was virtually dead, but 30 minutes later is was packed.  we started with the lamb sweetbread, which my friend highly recommended.  i had teh pork loin for my antree and i must say cooked to perfeciton.  i never eat much of the pork fat because it's never tasty or satisfying to my waist line, but friends me likies the pork fat at hereford.  savoury fatty goodness with the nice crunch of a perfect pork rind.  mmmm mmmm good!  i'll take those inches to my waistline, thank you very much.  heck i even followed up with dessert and shared the poach pear with my pal.  i'll be back for more eats next time i'm in town.  simple, good food prepared spectacularly.

photos.caption: Photo of Hereford Road - London, United Kingdom. poached pear
Photo of Hereford Road - London, United Kingdom. lamb sweetbreads

C1KR_aGMefjmC3hVSD4lxQ.text: Just adding a note to last year's experience - and I've downgraded it a bit....If this was a review about the sticky date pudding - it would be five stars, no problem. It has to be London's best - soft, rich, super moist and a lake of really dark, delicious sauce. But other than pud, I felt rather, well, neglected at Hereford Road last night. I've always loved it before - and I'd had to charge 12 miles around London during the day because of the tube strike chaos, so I was really ready for a decent meal. First off, they forgot to bring any bread. All the other tables got some. But although they warned out mains would take at least 15 minutes, we didn't get anything to tide us over. Then, the vegetarian dish. C'mon, guys! I mean, I know you're famous for your meat and all, but you could vary the thing SLIGHTLY. In two years. Barley, pumpkin, goats cheese. Not so much. I've had it 4 times now, the first time it was pretty good, the second time mushy, the third time dry, this time just bland. Did you forget the seasoning? What's wrong with - say - offering some lentils and girolles, which were on the menu alongside the duck? Anyway, just a thought.Oh, and my chunk of pudding was gorgous, but way smaller than the girl on the next table. Just saying.

_r4fXNpnWXB_22ZEBCFu_A.text: In the last three months I've eaten here three times, twice in the last week. The menu changes regularly and as others have noted the food is excellent, with a wonderful emphasis on local food and nose to tail items. I had excellent faggot, liver and sweatbreads. The service is capable and the selection of wines in  1/2 litre jugs is good (along with many more by the bottle). Do give it a go!

wM4os-SOiEyabJPByqqiFw.text: Really loved this place.  Traditional English food done in a modern and inventive way.  There were three of us, and everything we had was delicious.  Like eating in silence delicious.  Wines were great, and the service was friendly and helpful.  And the prices are reasonable to boot.  Definitely recommend this place.

Cl2zAZVKoQ_LBXLDnipHqQ.text: How I rejoiced when a St John alum brought the goods to my neck of the woods!  And not just anyone - this is the former head chef.  While not comparable to my love of St John (see my reviews for St John and St John Bread & Wine), I did find love here as well.The menu feels very St John - there's your requisite offal (sweetbreads, brains and cheeks), your fresh local veg (kale, artichoke, peas), your meaty mains (lamb, veal, chicken) and your traditional desserts (sticky date, chocolate and creme fraiche, cheese plate).  I started with an exquisite smoked eel with horseradish dish that was the best I've ever had.  A main of pork chop was tasty if a bit plain and my cheese plate was as good as any good British cheese plate.  But I picked at my companions' food as well, and food envy kicked in for an amazing calves' liver and a melt-in-your-mouth cut of beef.  I would maybe knock another half a star off if I could - huge skylight aside, something with the interior decor/atmosphere doesn't sit well with me.I will definitely be back (and maybe more adventurous).

rVzR5HchKBr4DWIgC3bGiQ.text: Situated in an old butcher's shop near Notting Hill, Hereford Road's simple and sparse interior allows the food do the talking with its seasonal British menu that relies on high quality ingredients. Similar to St John, where the chef trained, Hereford Road has a focus on offal, but it is also well known for its simple yet accomplished fish dishes.

2B1A1vq9fkNZ688skYKgMg.text: When my father told me he wanted to bring us here for a good English meal, I thought "Blaaah English food? This is going to be awful." Boy, was I wrong. I was so surprised and impressed with this place. Although some of the items on the menu seemed bizarre and daunting, I absolutely loved everything I tried. All the produce and ingredients were absolutely fresh. Hereford Road's menu changes based on the produce available to them which is a farmers market/farm-to-table quality I feel I rarely see outside of California. The actual restaurant contrasts greatly with its traditional food - the place is very modern with lots of steel and sharp accents - which creates a really great juxtaposition to its location in town home. Among the food highlights were the terrine pate, the rabbit, the steak, slip soles and the mullet (no I don't mean the hairstyle). Their desserts were also delicious - the chocolate cake was to die for. The wine list was also very good and affordable. In fact, the entire meal was surprisingly affordable considering how great the quality of the food was! The staff was incredible friendly and helpful as well. I would definitely love to come back here and highly recommend it to anyone looking for a good English meal! The space is relatively small so book in advance if you have a large group.

VSxYkfEkVsrUufSGwBpRMQ.text: [Non-photo Review] For full review, with pictures, please see here: laissezfare.wordpress.co…  HEREFORD ROAD - A ST JOHN FOR THE WEST SIDE? Our new local? As is the wont these days, Hereford Road operates an A4 single-sheet menu that allegedly changes each day according to what's fresh in the kitchen (FYI  the daily menu is also updated on their website). Think St John, Bocca di Luppo, Great Queen Street, etc. It's a great concept in theory, especially for a place purporting to be a 'local' restaurant, as the 'local' customers can come back often and never get bored. I have to admit I was quite intrigued by some of the choices on offer when we went on a Thursday night in mid-December. There were some very interesting dishes, including a few things I'd never even heard of before, and I know a bit about offal. I was particularly intrigued to hear our waiter describe the process of making 'Bath Chap', and decided I had to have some of that after understanding what it was and how it's prepared. The simple explanation is that it is a particular piece of pork from the lower cheek of pigs from the Wilthshire/Somerset area; it is fully de-boned, then placed in brine, then usually cooked in breadcrumbs  at Hereford Road they also add some 'aromatic herbs', but they wouldn't tell me which ones (even when I asked the chef on the way out). But enough about particular piggies from Bath. The four of us eventually decided on our dishes and began the waiting game. As we relaxed in our spacious booth, we attempted to talk over the very large table to our left, which must have been an office out on their Christmas party. I have to say that while the design of the restaurant is very nice  replete with red leather booths and simple yet smart tables, color schemes and furnishings  the acoustics are pretty atrocious on a busy night like the one on which we visited. As we tried to hear each other, a waiter brought out some bread, which was of the soft white loaf variety, and while freshly baked was not particularly memorable. Starter 1: Lamb Breast, Laverbread & OatmealMy starter of lamb breast was a new dish for me. The lamb breast (or brisket) had been cooked inside a fried oatmeal crust which had laverbread mixed into it. The flavor combination was bold but worked well, with the fairly strong lamb taste being offset by the fried oatmeal and the mineral, sea flavors of the laverbread (think oysters). Not something you eat every day, but not bad at all. 7/10. Starter 2: Marinated Smoked Haddock, Potato & HorseradishMy starter was good, but Mrs. LF couldn't stop raving about hers  and this is not often something she does. She said that the dish was really amazing. The smoked fish was about the best I've had and everything on the plate was seasoned to perfection  the potato and horseradish were particularly good  and I wanted to keep coming back for more. At the end of it, I took some of the bread and mopped up the remaining bits. It was a well balanced, simple but nearly perfect dish, and that potato salad was to die for. 9/10. Main Course 1: Roast Loin of Middlewhite Pork, Bath Chap, Swede & KaleMy main of Middlewhite Pork was also good. The pork meat itself was tender and flavorful (but not overly so) and I really enjoyed the accompaniments of kale and mashed swede, whose colors of green and orange also lent the plate a nice visual appeal. The only real problem with the dish was that the layer of rind on the outside of the circular cut was simply too hard to eat. This was a shame, because I really love crackling when it's well done, but you felt you were in danger of breaking a tooth if you ate this stuff (of course, I managed to down a bit of it anyway). But the real eye opener was the Bath Chap, which was utterly delicious. It is quite fatty, so I was glad that there was only a thin slice of it, but the flavor was new to me and very appealingsort of liked cooked ham, but better than any I've had in the UK, with a nice hint of seasoning. 7/10. Main Course 2: Lemon Sole, Roast Jerusalem Artichoke & Mustard LeafUnfortunately, the good luck ran out for Mrs. LF at this point in the meal. She said that her main course of Lemon Sole was really average. I have had Lemon Sole in France and know what it can and should be like, and this didn't even touch the one that my mom makes. The sole was slightly overcooked, a bit dry and rather plain. Also, there wasn't much evidence of the sauce. The fish itself was fresh and it tasted healthy, but it wasn't delicious; it simply didn't taste as it should. The sole is a delicate fish and this one didn't melt in my mouth as it should have. 5/10. Wine: 2007 Bourgogne, Cuvée Margot, Olivier LeflaiveOur chosen booze for the meal was a very quaffable entry-level red Burgundy from Olivier Leflaive. This is not the same as the more famous Domaine Leflaive (which, along with Lafon, is probably one of the few kings of burgundy to my

lKfe_zltKlgHC6AmhxZhvA.text: Excellent British food in a modern, airy, and bright space.Leek vinaigrette was fantastic.  Guinea Fowl w/ lentils was excellent, as was the braised rabbit.  Well priced and selected wine list.tip: there are booth-like tables for two at the front with a love-seat configuration.  very cool.

6vlcKEA-QAaBe-JT1J5Qqg.text: This should be a 2-part review.  With explanations.  I am not a big meat eater, and having spent ten years in California, the land of salads, pork belly (and anything involving the kidneys, liver or brains of any animal) is a bit much.  However, I would give 5 stars to the fact that they go all out and seriously hard-core british with the menu.  Even my vegetarian dish tasted meaty.  That and the too sparse decor, and somewhat brusque service knock it down to three stars for me.  Someone who loves pork belly may feel differently!

Rdmbdv5S8bXq4c_zSX3ENQ.text: This place is brilliant, great food at a reasonable price in a classy setting. Great for a romantic night for two or dinner with friends.See if you can grab one of the cute booths along the wall across from the kitchen.We started with the spinach soup with snails. Having made spinach soup at home many times, I wondered why I never thought to put snails in it -- but that is why you go out to eat -- to be surprised and inspired. The earthy flavours of the snails and spinach were excellent together. I'd seen a BBC programme about "potted shrimp" earlier in the week, so when I saw potted crab on the menu, I had to try it. I don't know how to put this, but it was the most crab-y tasting crab I have had in a very long time. The wine list was reasonably priced by London standards -- most wines under 40 quid and main dishes under 15.Gluten-free notes: Nearly all of the menu items are naturally gluten free and they were happy to advise.

mLKK4hGi7Pjoaxd7ePYT7w.text: Ate here last Friday night for our anniversary dinner. Had 9:30pm reservations and when we arrived a table was waiting for us. We were seated across from the kitchen, which was great as we got to watch the chefs prepare the dishes and interact with them as well. The daily menu was varied and wonderful. We tried a range of appetizers and for dinner had the calf liver and rabbit stew. Both were incredible and very reasonably priced. The service was great and overall the dinner was fantastic for what seems like a very small, neighborhood restaurant. We'll definitely be coming back on our next trip to London would highly recommend Hereford Road to anyone with a curios palate who's willing to try new things.

n8nZmb3VSMQTwYqyNUQiHw.text: This is probably the best restaurant with national kitchen that I recently had lunch in. They offer a set lunch menu with 2 or 3 courses from Monday to Friday which is both delicious and on a budget. Perhaps the thing that made me biggest impression was the long wine list with selected varieties and manufacturers to supplement the perfect taste of the food. The interior is very cosy and the service is also flawless.

GpqUxARzYBuV6YJLTvqmVg.text: The place to go if you like more stimulating dishes, over and above more standard British menus. Dark décor but the dishes are there to be tasted more than admired.So good we went back for our engagement meal in December '14

Y26fBPjcM2RAPhlnMNfbAQ.text: Simple but good British food. I personally love all the dishes but I find the price point slightly expensive for what it is...  Many of the dishes are not well crafted although mostly taste good and price points almost suggest that plates would be slightly more curated.  For this reason 3 start - it is a great place to take visitors to showcase the real British food instead of fish and chips and ale pies.

lpl5unUdDztwW9YXQ6nn0A.text: Came here early on a Thursday evening and the restaurant was ominously empty. However it filled up very quickly. I loved the quirky decor and the service was excellent. I had the leek vinaigrette which was an amazing dish, followed by the lamb rump, also delicious. Afterwards I had the bakewell tart; very good. The wine was very reasonably priced. Dinner for two with alcohol was £130. An enjoyable experience and well worth the good reviews.

_B_9vj3lpBeqIRHdeWKPjw.text: I love this new breed of English chefs who have real pride in the heritage of their food.  We ordered some grilled squid, which was fantastic, and as recommended by friends - they said to order the offals, which were not awful (sorry.  I had to say that.)  I ordered some calf's liver with onions and mash, which was so good it didn't even taste like liver.  My boyfriend ordered the duck confit, which he gave a huge thumbs up.  Finishing the night with some apple crumble was perfect, although we both burned our mouths because the apple was so piping hot.  Although we didn't have a reservation, they managed to seat us and didn't rush us out of the restaurant.  Top notch service and quality.  I'll be back!

Zhtsf-TzSFUsZbGegsX38w.text: My BF and I came for lunch. I had the set lunch, 3-courses (starter, main and dessert) for 16.50 euros and my BF had the express lunch (main course, a glass of wine and a cup of coffee) for 9.50 euros. Not bad at all. It is a mid-price range establishment and is supposed to offer authentic British food, but I wouldn't know anything about British food because I'm not from there. Its layout is clean and simple with a mix of retro booth seating and table seating. Starter: I'm disappointed I did not take better notes on this dish but I do have a picture of it. It is some sort of hummus-like spread on toasts. Main dish, Fried smelt: This was my favorite dish. I believe its smelt but I'm not completely sure. It is a long skinny fish that is mildly fishy and oh-so pleasant to devour. I love small fishes like smelt and sardines. The dish is served with arugula, lemon and tartar sauce. Uncomplicated and delicious. Main dish, Fried dover sole: Served with a courgette (zucchini) salad and a lemon wedge. There's not much to say about this dish. It's as good as fried fish can get. Sole/flounder is a flat fish. It has a delicate but firm taste and is a medium fishy fish. I can't remember what dessert we had, I know it was a pudding of some sort. I do remember walking out full and satisfied. The food here looks underwhelming perhaps. It lacks presentation and appears so simple but don't be fooled by its appearance. Simplicity can be exquisite. This place is a great value and I highly recommend it.

hr8BO4ckhVStfPtAjilaAg.text: Everything about our meal was excellent and, in my book, the mark of a really good restaurant is when I simply cannot decide what to order - I would have liked every single one of the dishes.  But the stand out starter was an artichoke and rocket salad that was intensely flavoured.  And the venison for the main course was stunning.  An interesting wine list also.

wBkOcQAAkUG_9OX0Qqm6Jw.text: We're not big "British food" fans. But this place has won us over. Notting Hill is quite the charming neighborhood. This restaurant adds to the neighborhood's charm. We started with the quail. It wasn't the best. Meat wasn't as tender as it should have been. But our mains were amazing. We enjoyed the braised rabbit leg and pork belly. Their sides are equally flavorful. Not over salted, but perfectly seasoned. Ended with their eton mess, a refreshing summer dessert. And we enjoyed our stroll home. We'll be coming back.

EI0WqV85G1ZeQo73kQ2Hig.text: I wanted to love this place. Twice. Staying just a few yards from Hereford Road, which had great reviews, I thought I was blessed. Instead, one time, having made and confirmed reservations we had to wait for a table for more than 30 minutes. By the time the menus came, and by the time the food was served an hour and 20 minute had passed. I can't even remember what the food was like, I was so unhappy. Why didn't we leave? We were already there, it was getting late so other restaurants in the area would be full or closing for the night. We had already invested the time. Surely it couldn't take much longer (but it did).  OK, we thought maybe the restaurant was having a really off night. So, we reserved during the following year's visit ( May 2013), and once again the service failed us. Drastically. We won't be going back.

rIoc8wPYmUCDNACQPVmmBg.text: The food here is really very good. The service is a letdown. The waiter was astonishingly rude. I also witnessed him bullying the waitress. Awful business. A great shame really since the chefs here do a great job.

q6FxWWKRJMSaZvxk9Z5ngw.text: Having decided to eventually try a Sunday roast, I googled and found this place. Awesome. Great, not too big, with the most amazing circle window in the ceiling, not overly busy on Sunday. Attentive staff. We had wood pigeons and delicate pork  both delightful. The veggies were beautifully cooked.Hot choc pudding with ice-creams made some of us smile. Would always recommend and would love to come back.

InixxChUrzbOrs-r21O_vw.text: Last day in London and you want to eat some outstanding British food!! What do you do?? Let me recommend you an truly fantastic restaurant, HEREFORD ROAD in Hereford Road London. Here is an outstanding meal. Start with Beetroot, hazelnut and Goat's curd. Really excellent salad.  Then follow it with the Blythburg Pork  Belly. A wonderful combination of crispy skin and soft delicious meet.  To end, you can not miss the Sticky date pudding and pouring cream. A delicious and decadent treat!!  If you combine it with the right wine.  You are definitely going home very happy. Don't miss and cheers.

w27M7wypQPSGzFiYChAqdQ.text: This is the restaurant we go to regularly as a family. This means it has to be excellent and the staff are very patient and considerate, as trying to please everyone in my family is a herculean task.Food is simple, british bistro, similar to St. John's.The bread is delicious, not a great place for vegetarians but the there is always something on the menu for them. Agree with previous review, the sitcky date pudding is obscenely good.Prices are very reasonable considering the standard of cooking and quality of ingredients.

38QnTKc38wBRcd1XsW8Y9A.text: The menu is very British with game animals and such... I had the 2-course set lunch which I guess is a good deal at £13. I say "I guess" because I didn't really like my food very much... Had the crispy pork (too dry?) and the braised rabbit (probably not their fault and I just don't like rabbit). I tried my sister's onglet though and that was good. Service was slow and we weren't lacking for anything in particular, but I just had the impression overall of it being a bit cold and neglectful.So it's okay, but unless price is the main concern, I would recommend Le Cafe Anglais instead which is just a few blocks away.

gzl2ITRp5X1Bko-URDVpCw.text: My partner and I lived in London for a while and Hereford Road quickly became our favorite place. Amazing traditional British food, walking distance from our place and solid service every single time. We went there pretty much every other week for a little more than a year, so we can say it's as consistent as it gets.Everything from the bread (beautiful crust) to pudding (you must have the sticky date pudding) is executed perfectly. Don't miss the sweetbreads and the livers, as well as the ox tail and the roe shoulder. Honestly, you could just randomize and whatever you picked would be perfect. Other notables are the buttermilk pudding, calf's brains, kidneys and the goose with quince cheese.Worth flying from San Francisco just to have dinner there!

PzHW78Qf-XaayAkkandxDg.text: Hmmm tricky one the Hereford, on some points this was a knock-out restaurant, excellent relaxed service and interesting British food. The food is traditional British and I mean traditional. The menu when I went included pig's face (brawn) and oysters fresh from Essex. Now, I love my oysters and appreciate they can be a bit hit or miss, but I didn't feel great about 30 minutes or so after my half dozen. Added to that my colleague (who I will admit is a slightly gluttonous individual) who was rather ill on his way home on the tube. I don't put this down to bad oysters actually, but rather the fact that he had a rather unwise combination of brawn, oysters (this was just to start), followed by lamb, rice pudding and a cheese plate. That combination washed down with 3 glasses of wine is enough to make anyone vomit. But enough of that, I had the aforementioned oysters to start and faggots for main. Beautifully cooked and tasty. I finished with a sorbet to cleanse my palate and to settle my stomach - it either worked or I have a stomach of iron (probably the latter).Anyways, don't let my colleague's experience put you off trying this delicious slice of British cuisine. Great food, great prices (more like gastro pub than restaurant) - just be a little wary of the oysters, definitely not for the faint hearted.

ce3K5m1VSqiYC8Za1CgC2Q.text: Fabulous! Recommended by a friend, native of London. Stopped here for lunch and was not disappointed. The 2-course lunch special was reasonably priced and options very good. I had the duck egg and beet salad for starter, whole mackerel for main. Both were divine. Highly enjoyable.

S4tKWjVBx5woWb6OVkVDFA.text: Delicious food. Good service. Original menu. This was our second visit. Very glad we came back.

lXFaiCjMTyDnr8J5BJMnfg.text: Eh. I always feel a pang of guilt when palates more 'Elite than mine (in the Yelpest sense of the word) find joy in places I got none from, but alas, here we are again. I live uber-close to this place and was aiming at taking my hungry bodily shell down to Alounak, but my friend and I passed by this place, thought it looked promising and decided that we'd be just like those carefree disenfranchised Shoreditch hipsters we so love to hate and have dinner without - oh Jesus- reservations here. The food was bland - it's hard to make things that are not usually bland taste bland, but this was indeed the case, and we tried four different things. Our appetizers ( duck livers and a cheesy concoction) were amateur hour, and his pheasant and my duck - both usually strong, gamey meats, were no more than slobs of game over undercooked ( severely undercooked, actually, more like pebbles on a beach undercooked) green peas and beans. Desserts was meh. Drinks were meh. I mean, no one had a Totes Vom moment or anything, and I honestly feel that the chef just had Mercury in his house or a bad Tinder date, cause this place has potential. Perhaps. See, I am so nice.

EDq3JLzt9-pZV9eQX7q3Zg.text: I love the ambiance here. Modern and relaxed with great food! It's great for a relaxed dinner with friends or an intimate meal.We tried the Grilled Asparagus and Melted Butter, Whole Line Caught Seabass, Roast New Potatoes and Parsley, a pork dish and a couple of the desserts. Everything was delicious and the service was great as well. Overall a very good meal!

photos.caption: Photo of Hereford Road - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Hereford Road - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Hereford Road - London, United Kingdom

A3ra4JYkBKGNKjzJXtusgg.text: One of my favorites, place to go for all kind of meats, great place for modern British cuisine!Quail, duck leg, culf brain, pork belly, games - they're masters in meaty field. And they bake wonderful, crusty bread at the place.Tom(head chef) was previously head chef at St. John a read and Wine, so no surprise wine list is also impressive here.

zhipWGPWDHz1Fnb81FeXnA.text: Been here once before but unfortunately couldn't get a table for dinner, next day I went back for lunch and I was one of the first in for lunch service! I chose a corner booth to sit in. Service was superb(also maybe because there went any customers yet) they have a simple menu which is great. I opted for the 2 course (£11.95) ordered a leek appetizer with a grilled mackerel. The presentation of these dishes are superb. See attached pics. The leek was great, I usually do not eat leek so it was new to me. There was a minced up egg on it which was excellent. For my main, the mackerel to my surprise a whole entire mackerel came! Good value! But it was hard for me to eat because of the little bones. A bit dry but it also has a side salad which pairs well with it. I would probably order something different next time. The service times were great I was in and out in 40 minutes.  Treated myself to a latte too (£2.95). Well made, sugar cubes at the side which is much more classier than bagged sugar. ;) All in all, it was great and I would definitely come again. I heard their menus change quite a bit. And during lunch the set course lunches are a great deal. If you want a 3 course it is (£13.95) I believe.

photos.caption: Photo of Hereford Road - London, United Kingdom. Latte (2.95)
Photo of Hereford Road - London, United Kingdom. 2 course for (11.95)
Photo of Hereford Road - London, United Kingdom. Mackerel main (2 course for 11.95)

78CPJBgwehGzAC8VSNCmcw.text: 3.5 stars for Hereford Road's "traditional british" food on the more upscale side (afterall, this aint pub food!). I found this place on a list of London's top 50 restaurants & the ingredients are definitely different from your average restaurantvery nice staff who was patient enough to explain the daily menu to us!--most ppl get bottled water or wine but you can ask for tap--yummy complimentary bread--Ham hock salad: good flavor, but not amazing--Skate: i guess i'm not a fan of bone-in skate, so i've had better BUT i really liked the cauliflower it came with--Roe shoulder (deer) w/ carrots for two: delicious stew-like dish but a few parts of the roe were dry... requires 40 minutes to prepare!--Chilled rice pudding w/ jam: good but I wish I went for ice cream--Spiced rhubarb cake w/ ice cream: moist!NOTE: the walk over to the restaurant felt SHADY from the closest tube stop, i wouldn't walk in that neighborhood alone at night

photos.caption: Photo of Hereford Road - London, United Kingdom. spiced rhubarb cake w/ ice cream
Photo of Hereford Road - London, United Kingdom. chilled rice pudding w/ jam
Photo of Hereford Road - London, United Kingdom. skate w/ cauliflower

127lcbLcTrIq-UNgDNGvqA.text: As it was the eve of my all-important day of birth, I had some high expectations from HR, even going so far as to request a "nice table" on my OpenTable reservation form when I booked it a couple weeks prior. We walked in to discover a table tucked away on a raised portion of the restaurant (just before a staircase that led into a booth-heavy area one level below). The booths looked roomier and comfier than our tight table. When I asked the waiter if we could move down there, he said, politely "no, they're not available." (This is only worth mentioning because throughout the course of the evening, two of the booths were never touched/remained empty. We did end up discovering that our table was a pretty sweet spot because we could "see" nearly the entire restaurant from it. Not bad, but still.)My party of four ate very well (I'm uploading pics too). Whether it was fish, rabbit or something else, we all loved our meals. The only "eh" dish was the terrine. After St. John's and Arbutus' versions, I was disappointed in HR's terrine - just a bit bland and (worse) dry. But again, the rest of the meal - all of our meals - were quite divine.Our waiter (once he found out it was my bday eve) was a hoot and a holler and would often focus all of his attention to me w/ the just the right amount of sarcasm. I grew to love him, even after his refusal to give us the dang booth. He really won me over when he presented my apple cobbler with a candle in it. Cute!  ... but he didn't sing.Anyway, very good food, great wine and snappy service. We had a fine time!

photos.caption: Photo of Hereford Road - London, United Kingdom. Fish dish.
Photo of Hereford Road - London, United Kingdom. Fish dish.
Photo of Hereford Road - London, United Kingdom. Rabbit

xKd6QwMeMbnvY2qitukFiw.text: I had read that Hereford served traditional British food. As an American, this stereotype means fish and chips, Shepard's pie and a possibility of bland food. This however, was none of these things. Upscale and and minimal,  the menu was short and focused on game, fish and some, ah, other animal parts.We stuck with known meat items and were happy with the preparation of almost everything we ordered. We had salads and grilled asparagus to start. The asparagus was a particular highlight of the meal. I like asparagus quite a bit and this really pulled out every good flavor. The steak we had was also very good and came with a sauce, that, while enjoyed, we were not quite sure what it was.  My cousin's fish came full skeleton-in, along with a plate for once it was removed. This made the fish somewhat difficult to eat, though the taste was lovely. The service was also good. The only other issue we had was that while we came for lunch, one of the items we had initially planned on ordering was already out. Note to other Americans- they do have tap water but you need to specify this is what you want. Bottled water seems to be the norm here.

5N5U1deu2dyDYKjcnf6qow.text: Came here at 6pm on a Tues evening. The restaurant had just opened for the night and we were the only ones there for the first hour or so.  From the outside the restaurant looks quite small but they have converted the back and made it a very trendy space that seats many. I loved the decor, there was no music playing but I can imagine the restaurant getting quite romantic on busy weekends.I ordered the ox heart to start and the pork belly for mains. My husband ordered the lamb sweetbread and pork belly also. We paired these with a bottle of Malbec (French equivalent) which I was very happy with. The knowledgeable waiter recommended the wine for us.I was a little hesitant ordering the ox heart but I was surprisingly delighted by the choice I made. I thought they over did the salt but apart from that the food was absolutely gorgeous! The pork belly came with a HUGE crackling. This was the main reason we came here and it was delicious. I miss my pork crackling since we cant get it in the States.Definitely a place to try if you want to try modern British cuisine.

in46kc8Rk3wdItYiyGtggg.text: Returning to London 5 years after living there, I felt a bit lost on the food front. Everything I knew that was good may or may not still be good... indeed, they may or may not still be there. My friend and I wanted British food so St. John first came to mind. But there are also so many other options to try...! I'm really glad we gave Hereford Road a go. Tucked on a quiet street in Notting Hill, this place was warm and cozy, a bit of a high end gastropub. As we set out for traditional British food, we decided to go all out. We got the FRIED CALF BRAIN, LAMB'S SWEETBREADS, POTTED CRAB, and DEVILED LAMB KIDNEYS. Everything was delicious. My favorite was the lamb kidneys. Every aspect of the dish was flavorful, including the veggies and the potatoes. If I could do it over again, I would cut out the potted crab so I could eat more lamb kidneys. The crab was good but didn't stand out as much as the others.Make reservations early to avoid eating a 9:30 pm dinner. It's also not the easiest place to get to, the closest tube stop being Bayswater. But it is definitely a gem off the beaten path.

photos.caption: Photo of Hereford Road - London, United Kingdom. Lamb's sweetbreads - great!
Photo of Hereford Road - London, United Kingdom. Potted crab - good but no too special.
Photo of Hereford Road - London, United Kingdom. Deviled lamb kidneys - every part of this dish was delicious!

HtBlDu9whbsFVsjWQzTxtw.text: After learning that Tom Pemberton is a co-owner of Hereford Road (i love St John's) I had to try it during my last visit of London. We were initially skeptical because upon arrival at 18:30, the place was completely empty. We started off with a chilled red wine, Grignolino D'Asti. It was almost like a rose wine, without much of a scent. Refreshing nonetheless.The starter of Duck livers with green beans and tarragon was great. The tarragon added a hint of an anise flavor which was not too overpowering. For mains, we ordered the venison and pork belly pie (meant to serve 2). The waitress initially heard us incorrectly and thought we ordered two venison dishes. When that arrived, I think it looked really good but we did want what we initially ordered so we had it sent back. The manager was really courteous about everything. Since we had to wait an extra 25 minutes, they comped our appetizer which was a nice gesture.

VTJhcYXaoJkurlSYwkLM_w.text: Two "nos" too many.  We made reservations on open table for dinner.  Got there right on time and place was virtually empty except for one noisy table.  They attempted to seat us immediately adjacent to the them.  We discretely asked if we could be seated in one of the 3 empty booths.  Nope.  After they seated us again in the original seats, it was pretty miserable.  We asked if there were any other options amongst all the empty seats we could see.  All they had was "upstairs".  Two steps up and 10 feet way adjacent to the bar - they were available, but we would need to be gone in an hour and 15 minutes.  Another " no".  Strike 2.  Not willing to endear a strike 3.  We really aren't that picky of a couple, but this was pretentious and rude. So, we can't speak to the food, but we were really happy at the greek place around the corner!!!

8alN_gJPSHjUHIsILSdeQw.text: Very 'NYC-ish' to me - trendy decor, good service  and reasonably priced delicious food.  Absolutely loved it!   The menu changes daily and can be quite adventurous.  We had lamb sweetbreads and calf brain to start and a beautiful pork belly and Barnsley lamb chop for mains.  The mains were quite large so could have skipped the starters.  Everything was delicious--- my chef husband even loved it which doesn't happen very often!  Entrees ranged from £11 - £17 and starters from £5-£8.  I had wine by the glass for about £7 --- total bill around £70 or £80..

xBo1aGvGvs0440wHbJa6AA.text: Good food and at good value, but the service was lacking and the decor is a bit confused. An OK option for the area.

Qzv7-9gwFBLfLk2gFvrnag.text: This restaurant has great value.  We went here for lunch and just missed the express lunch (lamb shank, salad, glass of wine, coffee for £9.5).  Instead me and my brother got the 3 course lunch (2 course 13.5; : course 15.5)Appetizer1. Duck breast 5/5Amazing!  A must try.  Probably the best thing we eat!1. Parsnip soup- solid on a cold day 3.5/5MainSteak 5/5 - chips were good.DesertA milky mix of jelly and cream for a flan type of desert.

Py6ZXo0sUCe2VbXTjOcpzg.text: I was just in London recently and a friend took me here. It's down the road from her place, and she kept telling me how good it was.Halfway through eating the Pork Belly, I had an overwhelming desire to give her a huge hug and a kiss.  She's plenty cute, but that's not why... That Pork Belly was so good, it almost made cry. Everything I saw come out of the kitchen looked really great too. We had an adorable server who was super sweet and helpful walking me through the menu. I was excited to eat at a place the did a fresh take on British cuisine.  This place is really delicious, go there!

5eu2j3m1vfyxELv70G24-Q.text: Another recommended restaurant from a friend, this one definitely did not disappoint.  This was one of our first meals in London and we wanted to try a little of everything so we ordered 2 appetizers, 2 entrées, 2 desserts.  The restaurant has the open kitchen concept as well as outdoor seating, which I am a fan of.  The food itself was surprisingly good.  For appetizers we ordered the Mussels and the sweetbreads, both delicious.  The mussels were big, meaty, and full of flavor.  It wasn't rubbery or overcooked.  This was actually the first time Ive had sweetbreads and it was awesome.  Served with parsley, capers, and a medley of other herbs that made the dish irresistible from me and and my wife.  For the entree, I ordered the braised rabbit stew and the wifey ordered the pork dish.  Mine was above average, hers was amazing.  Although the rabbit was fall off the bone good, there werent many elements to the dish.  The pork had the loin and pork belly with a crispy skin.  A very simple dish but bursting with flavors.  Three tables down from us, there was a party that got their plate before us and you could hear him foodgasm over his pork dish.  Yes, my wife did the same.  The desserts we had the Eton mess which was like a lot of whip cream and chunks of rhubarb, something you would definitely not see in the states.  And I had the safe choice, the apple crumble.  Both were good, mine was better.Staff is friendly, space was not cramped, and I would definitely recommend to anyone.

photos.caption: Photo of Hereford Road - London, United Kingdom. Mussels
Photo of Hereford Road - London, United Kingdom. Pork. 3 ways. Yum
Photo of Hereford Road - London, United Kingdom. Braised rabbit stew

Aezw0fF8kY8GT4mGoubKtQ.text: This restaurant served me the greatest meal of my life. Although it took a while to get the waiter to notice us and serve us, the rest of the meal was spectacular. We started with the calves brain appetizer. This is something I never would have tried before, but I was feeling bold and it paid off! I then had the rabbit and turnips with pancetta In this amazing broth. I could have eaten that meal 100 times and would still want more. This restaurant made my trip to London even more memorable. I will tell everyone I know about this!

7iRxex91OqbZJ6CQtdPkyQ.text: Went for a very late dinner. the place is a cozy casual/elegant restaurant. excellent fresh food and super friendly staff. the owner/chef previously worked at St. John (another great restaurant in London). Spotted: Ralph Fiennes dining with a writer in this low-key resto
